intro: Ipomopsis congesta var. ochroleuca, commonly known as the white-flowered ipomopsis, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that are typically white or pale yellow, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant has a compact, bushy growth habit with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats like grasslands and rocky slopes. Its botanical significance lies in its role as a component of native plant communities and its ornamental value in gardens.
